entry.title: SAP Build Work Zone Security
entry.content:
I've been spending quite some time recently diving deep into SAP Build Work Zone security, and let me tell you, it's a journey. Terms like #IAS, #BTP Subaccount #trusts, and #ShadowUsers can sometimes feel like a maze.

But then, an analogy clicked for me - the #DigitalMall and suddenly, the whole complex architecture started making perfect sense. I wanted to share this breakdown with all of you, hoping it helps.

Let's imagine SAP Build Work Zone as a bustling, modern Digital Mall, where users (you, the #shoppers) come to access various #stores (business applications) and "services" (collaboration features). Every security layer has a purpose, just like every part of a well run mall

#TheGrandOpening: Understanding this Digital Mall's Foundation

Before anyone even walks in, the mall has a master plan and a way to organize its offerings:

>>> SAP BTP Subaccount: Think of this as the Mall's Main Entrance & Security Gate. It's the primary gateway, controlling who can even step foot inside your digital space. It's where core permissions are managed.

>>> SAP Build Work Zone Tenant: This is your specific, unique instance of the Mall itself - your personalized shopping experience!

>>> #ContentManager: This acts like the Mall's Central Directory or Information Kiosk. It lists all the "stores" (your business applications) available within the mall, helping shoppers find what they need

>>> Content Providers: These are the "Department Stores" (like SAP S/4HANA
SuccessFactors) or even smaller "Boutiques" (your custom applications). They reside outside your immediate mall structure but integrate seamlessly, making their offerings available inside your Work Zone.

>>>>Stepping Inside: Your Identity & Basic Mall Access<<<<

Now, for the really crucial part: how does a "shopper" (your user) actually get into the Digital Mall, and how is their identity validated at the main entrance?

>>> #SAPCloudIdentityServices - Identity Authentication (IAS): The Mall's Central Security System / ID Proxy

This is the mandatory first stop for any user trying to enter your Work Zone mall. #IAS is your primary #IdentityProvider [IDP]

>>> #Proxy Mode: If your organization uses its own Corporate IdP (like Azure AD, Okta), IAS acts as a clever proxy. You authenticate against your corporate system, and IAS then receives that verified identity, federating it onward in a way Work Zone understands. It's seamless, you just show your corporate ID.

>>> #TheDigitalIdCard (SAML Assertion / OIDC Token): Once authenticated, IAS issues a secure token. This token is packed with vital information, essentially your digital "ID Card" that gets you past the main gate:

>>> #SubjectNameIdentifier (SNI): This is your main identifier (e.g., your Login Name or Employee ID). It's what the BTP Subaccount primarily uses.

#Assertion Attribute (often IAS UUID): This is a unique, stable, and persistent ID assigned by IAS. It's super important for internal Work Zone component communication later on, especially with the DWS (our "Community Center," which I'll cover in Part 2!)

---> Other standard user attributes like email, first name, last name.

SAP BTP Subaccount Trust Configuration: The Main Gate's Agreement with IAS

Your BTP Subaccount (the main gate) has a "trust agreement" with IAS. This allows it to confidently accept those digital ID cards (tokens) from IAS.

>>> #The XSUAA Shadow User: Your Mall Access Card. This is one of the most critical concepts

When a user successfully authenticates via IAS for the first time, a "Shadow User" record is either created or identified in the BTP Subaccount's internal user list. Think of this as your personal "Mall Access Card" record.

 

Why is it needed? Even if IAS knows who you are, the BTP Subaccount needs its own local record (the shadow user) to attach BTP Role Collections to it. These role collections are your "Mall-wide Privileges" (e.g., WorkZone_User, WorkZone_Admin) that determine what you can do across the whole Work Zone platform.

 

>>>> Crucial Point: If a shadow user doesn't exist (and automatic creation isn't enabled), login to Work Zone will fail because there is no local identity to attach permissions to.

Principal Propagation: Seamless Access to Department Stores!

Once you're in the mall and launch an app from an On-Premise Backend System (like an S/4HANA Fiori app via SAP Cloud Connector), you don't want to log in again, right?

This is where ##Principal Propagation comes in! Your identity (using the IAS SNI from the BTP trust) is seamlessly passed through the BTP Destination Service and SAP Cloud Connector directly to the backend system. The S/ 4HANA system then recognizes you and authorizes your access based on your roles within S/4HANA. It's like your Mall Access Card automatically opening the staff-only doors in a department store.

This is just the exciting first step of understanding Work Zone security. In Part 2, coming next.

The Digital Workplace Service (DWS) (the Mall's Community Center).

User and User List Provisioning (how the Community Center gets its member lists).

The critical differences between Internal vs. External Users (different types of Community Center members).

And how SCIM APIs are the "automated delivery trucks" for all this data!

Stay tuned for more insights, and in the meantime, I'd love to hear your thoughts or questions on this first part in the comments below!

Happy Work Zone-ing!

Lets connect and learn together ‚úåÔ∏è

entry.title: Re: Side by Side extension APPlication
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question. I'm very sorry for the late response.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves the issue?

It seems like you are encountering an authentication issue when trying to access your portal/workzone subscription site. This issue might be related to the configuration of identity providers and the integration between SAP BTP and SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

Possible Solutions

  1. Identity Provider Configuration:

    • Ensure that the SAP BTP subaccount is correctly configured to use the IAS of the S/4HANA Cloud. This involves setting up trust and federation with identity providers. You can refer to the documentation on Trust and Federation with Identity Providers Configuration of Integrated SAP BTP Apps for detailed steps.

  2. Communication Arrangements:

    • Verify that the communication arrangements are correctly set up in the S/4HANA Cloud. This includes ensuring that the correct user credentials are used and that the destination service is properly configured.

  3. Error Handling:

    • If you are seeing specific error messages, such as ‚ÄòRefused to connect‚Äô or ‚Äòunexpected AuthnResponse‚Äô, these might be related to domain allowlisting or multiple identity providers being enabled. Check the Configuration of Integrated SAP BTP Apps for troubleshooting steps.

  4. Session Management:

    • Consider configuring automatic sign-out settings to ensure that sessions are managed correctly across integrated applications. This can help prevent authentication errors related to session timeouts.

  5. Technical User Setup:

    • Ensure that the technical user for CPI is correctly set up with the necessary roles and permissions. If you are using a custom IAS, make sure that the technical user is configured to authenticate against it. You can find more information on setting up a technical user in the Technical User CPI with Custom IAS Technical user CPI with custom IAS blog.
[1] Configuration of Integrated SAP BTP Apps
[2] Technical user CPI with custom IAS
Kind regards, 
Henrike

entry.title: A GitHub action to update tenant subscriptions for multitenant SaaS applications on BTP
entry.content:
Introduction

When deploying a multitenant SaaS app on BTP using GitHub Actions, you may want to update tenant subscriptions after each successful deployment. While there are a couple of ways to approach this, they either require manual implementation, or they only solve the problem partially.

One obvious approach is to run cds-mtx upgrade as part of your deployment workflow. However, this only updates the database schemas and does not handle all tenant dependencies.

Another option is to call the SaaS Provisioning Service APIs directly. While this works, it requires you to roll your own implementation which might be a bit too much effort.

A custom GitHub action

To simplify this process, I created a reusable GitHub Action that automatically updates all tenant dependencies by leveraging the SaaS Provisioning Service APIs. You can find it here:

https://github.com/gbrfarkas/btp-saas-sub-update-action

The action can be integrated into your deployment workflow and provides clear status updates and error reporting directly in the pipeline output.

Here‚Äôs an example of how to use it:

uses: gbrfarkas/btp-saas-sub-update-action@v1
with:
  api-url: 'https://saas-manager.cfapps.<region>.hana.ondemand.com'
  token-url: 'https://<...>.authentication.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token'
  client-id: '...'
  client-secret: '...'
  timeout: 180
  interval: 10

To configure it, you‚Äôll need to provide:

  • The API endpoint and token URL for your SaaS Provisioning Service instance

  • Credentials (client ID and client secret)

  • Optional values for timeout and check interval (to control how often the action checks progress during updates)

Summary

This custom GitHub action provides a simple way to update all tenant subscriptions and dependencies in a multitenant SaaS BTP app which you can easily integrate into your deployment pipeline.

Hopefully some of you find this useful to automate subscriptions updates. It's still a bit experimental so use it at your own risk in a productive environment.

entry.title: Set Up Hyperscaler VPN Connection (AWS/Azure/GCP) template not visible in Request Services
entry.content:
Hi Team,

We are trying to raise a request for a new vpn connection to our private cloud but the template (Set Up Hyperscaler VPN Connection (AWS/Azure/GCP) ) is not visible when creating service requests. I tried requesting through "Assisted Service Request" but I got the following reply:

"We cannot proceed with this Service Request as it is created using Assisted Service Request Template, where we already have a dedicated Service Template for this service. Requesting service through the wrong template may lead to unnecessary back-and-forth interactions, delayed activity start, quality issues, and downtime misses. So we request you to create a Service Request with template "Set Up Hyperscaler VPN Connection (AWS/Azure/GCP)" "

Please advise how can we raise the request, I have been trying for a long time now and this has affected our go-live.

 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Set Up Hyperscaler VPN Connection (AWS/Azure/GCP) tem...
entry.content:
The reason why you are unable to raise request "Set Up Hyperscaler VPN Connection (AWS/Azure/GCP)" is because you don't have the necessary authorization to do so.

In order to submit a service request for the 'Set Up Hyperscaler VPN Connection (AWS/Azure/GCP)' template, an S-user must be authorized to Create Billable Service Requests at the customer number level.

Upon reviewing your S-user ID and your super administrator S-user, I found that the required authorization was only assigned at the installation level. Usually, you will need to contact your administrator listed in Users & Contacts - SAP for Me to have the authorization assigned. As your super administrator lacks the necessary authorization, I have manually updated the permissions for both S-user IDs to ensure that the required authorization is now assigned at the customer number level. Please clear your browser cache and attempt to submit the request again to verify that the issue has been resolved.

For more detailed information on S-user authorizations required the Private Cloud Service Request application, please refer to KBA 2669783 - S-user authorizations required for the Private Cloud Service Request application - SAP for Me 

If you encounter any further difficulties or require additional assistance, please do not hesitate to contact us.

Have a nice day!

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: SAP BTP now available on Microsoft Azure, AWS, and Google Cloud Marketplaces
entry.content:
At Sapphire Orlando 2025, we announced SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) availability through Hyperscaler Marketplaces.  I‚Äôm happy to share that SAP BTP services are now available for purchase through Microsoft Azure, Amazon Web Services (AWS), and Google Cloud Marketplaces in the United States. 

Why SAP BTP?   

SAP BTP is SAP‚Äôs platform for all SAP applications with over 33,000 customers, 3,000 partners, and 10,000 pre-built accelerators.  It empowers customers and partners with generative AI-powered development, automation, integration, data, and analytics across SAP and non-SAP applications, business processes, and beyond. Accelerate time to value with pre-built workflows and integrations across Finance, HR, Supply Chain, Procurement and more. Empower developers of all skills with tools and languages of their choice, and purpose-built frameworks for business application development. Leverage generative AI capabilities specialized in automating and extending mission-critical business processes.

 

 Here are the key benefits for purchasing SAP BTP through Hyperscaler Marketplaces: 

1. Maximize Cost Efficiency with Existing Cloud Commitments 

Existing customers of Microsoft Azure, AWS, and Google Cloud can use their committed spend agreements to purchase SAP BTP through their respective cloud marketplaces. The ability to channel unused commitments toward SAP BTP investments allows customers to optimize their budgets and drive more value from their relationships with the Hyperscaler providers. Customers gain greater financial flexibility and can ensure that every dollar spent accelerates their digital transformation initiatives. 

2. Accelerated Procurement and Deployment 

Existing customers are familiar with the purchasing process through their Microsoft Azure, AWS, and Google Cloud hyperscaler marketplaces, making it easy for them to discover, select, and purchase SAP BTP services in one centralized platform. SAP BTP can then be deployed directly on hyperscaler infrastructure that customers already have in place and rely on for scalability, security, and innovation. This process allows for accelerated procurement and deployment, meaning customers can start innovating with SAP BTP services faster than ever!   

3. Simplified Billing and Vendor Consolidation 

Through Microsoft Azure, AWS, and Google Cloud Marketplaces, customers receive consolidated billing and invoicing that allows them to manage all their hyperscaler cloud services in one place. This enables customers to have better visibility into their spend management, streamline administrative tasks, and ensure compliance with corporate procurement policies. It also reduces the complexity of managing different vendors. 

 

Get Started Today 

Customers in the Uinted States (US) now have the ability to purchase SAP BTP through the hyperscaler marketplaces and the flexibility to run SAP BTP services in their hyperscaler of choice. This reflects SAP‚Äôs vision for openness and flexibility and gives our customers the ability to integrate, extend, and innovate their SAP and non-SAP applications.   

To begin your SAP BTP journey, visit the Microsoft Azure, Amazon Web Services, or Google Cloud marketplaces for more information or get in touch with your SAP BTP specialist.  Whether you're looking to move, optimize, or innovate your SAP applications, or create new AI and data-driven experiences, we are ready to help you accelerate your transformation with SAP BTP!

entry.title: Getting Ready for AI-Assisted Applicant Screening in SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Getting Ready for AI-Assisted Applicant Screening in SAP SuccessFactors

Recruiting is one of the most time-consuming parts of HR. For many companies, every new job role attracts hundreds of CVs. Recruiters spend hours reading applications, hiring managers get frustrated waiting for shortlists, and candidates often feel lost in the process.

SAP SuccessFactors has introduced a new feature ‚Äî AI-assisted applicant screening, powered by Joule ‚Äî to make this easier. The idea is simple: the system can read applications, match skills to the job, and even rank candidates from best to least fit. This has the potential to change how recruiters work, but there is something important to understand.

This feature does not simply work out of the box. To get value from it, you first need to set up some important building blocks in your system.

What you need before enabling AI-assisted screening

Over the last few months of working with clients, I have seen that the success of AI-assisted screening depends on six key areas:

1. Recruiting Management (RCM)

This is the foundation. Without properly structured job requisitions, application templates, and candidate profiles, there is no data for AI to work on.

2. Job Profile Builder (JPB)

Job Profile Builder is where you define jobs, roles, competencies, and required skills. The better this is set up, the stronger the AI matching will be. Think of it as the dictionary that AI uses to understand your jobs.

3. Talent Intelligence Hub (TIH)

This is becoming more and more important. TIH provides a single skills framework across the system. When jobs and candidates speak the same ‚Äúskills language,‚Äù the AI can make much better decisions about fit and ranking.

4. Joule with AI Units License

Joule is the intelligence layer inside SAP SuccessFactors. With the AI Units license, Joule can power features such as skills extraction, candidate-job matching, stack ranking, and even generating interview questions. Without Joule and the license, the feature cannot be enabled.

5. Role-Based Permissions (RBP)

Permissions are often overlooked. Recruiters and hiring managers need access to view AI insights, while system administrators need access to configure and monitor AI services.

6. Clean and consistent data

The simplest, but often the hardest step. If job descriptions are vague, or candidate data is incomplete, the AI will not give useful results. Clean data is the backbone of any successful AI implementation.

Why stack ranking makes a difference

The most useful feature of AI-assisted screening is stack ranking. This means applicants are automatically sorted from best fit to least fit based on the job requirements and the skills framework.

This helps in many ways:

  • Recruiters save time by not manually scanning hundreds of CVs.

  • Hiring managers get a clear shortlist and understand why certain candidates are ranked higher.

  • Every applicant is checked in the same way, which makes the process more consistent and fair.

  • Recruiters get more time to focus on meaningful conversations with candidates instead of repetitive screening tasks.

A real example from practice

One global technology company I worked with introduced AI-assisted screening for their campus hiring. They received thousands of applications for a single drive. Normally, this would take recruiters several weeks to manage.

With stack ranking enabled, the system automatically highlighted the most relevant candidates. The results:

  • Screening time reduced by 40 percent

  • Recruiters could finally spend more time engaging with students

  • Hiring managers felt the shortlist was of much higher quality

The company is now planning to extend this approach to experienced hiring as well.

Final thoughts

AI-assisted applicant screening in SAP SuccessFactors is not about replacing recruiters. It is about helping them focus on people, not paperwork.

But success depends on getting the basics right. Recruiting Management, Job Profile Builder, Talent Intelligence Hub, Joule with AI Units, Role-Based Permissions, and clean data ‚Äî these are the real prerequisites.

Once these are in place, stack ranking can truly change the way hiring teams work ‚Äî making recruitment faster, fairer, and more consistent.

entry.title: Use of quartile position in SuccessFactors compensation for Compensation Planning
entry.content:
Scenario:

In today‚Äôs competitive job market, ensuring fair and strategic pay decisions is more crucial than ever. Hence organizations across industries are leaning into pay position driven frameworks to guide their compensation planning. Where Quartile positions can be used as an effective method and insightful feature.

What Are Quartiles in Compensation?

Imagine a salary range divided into four- five equal parts:

  • Minimum (Payrange Min/ Q1)
  • Lower Quartile (Q2)
  • Midpoint (Payrange Mid/Q3)
  • Upper Quartile (Q4)
  • Maximum (Payrange Max)

Each employee's salary can be mapped onto these quartiles and ranges, helping HR teams and compensation planners identify where an individual stands within the overall pay structure.

Interpreting the Quartile Breakdown to identify in which category employees falls:

Quartile

Salary Position

Implication

Q1 (0‚Äì25%)

Low Quartile

May deserve a larger merit adjustment

Q2‚ÄìQ3 (25‚Äì75%)

Fairly Paid

Standard merit increases or bonus planning

Q4 (75‚Äì100%)

Highly Paid

Could receive lower merit increases

 The approach on how the Q1, Q2, Q3 and Q4 derives may vary from company to company.

üéØ Why Does It Matter?

Understanding salary positioning helps answer key questions in the compensation planning process:

  • Is this employee paid lesser compared to peers?
  • Should this high-performing employee get a bigger merit increase?
  • Payrange could be a way to get one more step closer to pay equity

It also guides promotion decisions and budget planning, ensuring pay increases are targeted where they‚Äôre needed most.

How to use SF functionality to meet the Organizations need:

entry.title: Restrict Access of OAuth2.0 Clients with the Technical User purpose
entry.content:
Hi,

New updates keep arrive our way, let's review one of the latest and compare with the previous situation.  The feature I'm talking about is the new purpose for OAuth2.0 Clients, named the 'Technical user'. 

 

 

What's new about it?

The Technical User purpose allows you to create OAuth 2.0 clients that can be linked to all scoped roles within your SAP Datasphere tenant. This includes:

  • General roles at the tenant level
  • and/or Roles at the space level

By leveraging this setup, you can enforce granular access restrictions. This means you can precisely control what the technical user can access, ensuring compliance with security and governance requirements.

Let's compare the purposes side-by-side


Interactive UsageFor human users who log in interactively via OAuth. Requires re-authorization based on Refresh Token Lifetime. - Logging into the Command Line Interface (CLI)
- Consuming data via OData API		 
API AccessFor programmatic access to APIs, typically for integrations.- Using SCIM 2.0 API for user provisioning
- Transporting content via Cloud Transport Management
- Exporting logs (audit activities)
- Connecting SAP Signavio		Limited to API-level permissions (tenant wide however)
Technical UserFor system-to-system communication or automation without user interaction.- Same as API Access but with broader flexibility
- Can include tenant-level and space-level roles
- Ideal for background jobs, ETL processes, and automation		Can be linked to all scoped roles (tenant + space)

 

 

In short we can conclude the following:

  • Interactive Usage: Used for CLI & OData API's. Provide the client parameters to users who need to connect clients, tools, or apps to SAP Datasphere
  • API Access: Designed for API calls (SCIM 2.0 API's, transporting content) but role assignment is limited.
  • Technical User: Same as API Access  but offers full role assignment flexibility, making it the most powerful for automation and service accounts.

You can read how to use OAuth2.0 Clients to Authenticate against SAP Datasphere for yourself here:  https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_DATASPHERE/9f804b8efa8043539289f42f372c4862/3f92b46fe0314e8ba60720e409c219fc.html. And thanks for reading the blog! Hope you share your own experience with the purposes in the comment section.

Kind Regards, Thibault

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4 Migration
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question. I'm very sorry for the late response.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves the issue?

Running parallel S/4 migration projects can significantly impact SAP landscapes and processes. Here are some insights into how this can be managed effectively:

Impact on SAP Landscapes

  1. Three-System Landscape (3SL):

    • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition provides a 3-system landscape consisting of development, test, and production systems. This setup is crucial for managing parallel projects as it allows for separate environments for development and testing before changes are moved to production.
    • The introduction of Parallel Project Line (PPL) enhances the implementation experience by providing additional customizing and testing environments, allowing separation of subsequent implementation projects from continuous innovations in the existing productive environment.

  2. Transport Management:

    • Managing transport requests efficiently is vital. SAP provides tools like the Transport Organizer in Eclipse-based ABAP Development Tools and various SAP Fiori apps for managing and importing transport requests.
    • It‚Äôs important to manage developments and transports in milestones or tacts to ensure consistency and avoid errors due to wrong transport sequences.

Process Alignment and Retrofit

  1. SAP Cloud ALM:

    • SAP Cloud ALM can be used to manage the complexity of multiple open transports and ensure alignment across projects. It provides features for managing requirements, documentation, testing, and related transports.
    • The Feature Management application in SAP Cloud ALM helps keep an overview of transports or collection versions that belong together.

  2. Digital Discovery Assessment (DDA):

    • The DDA app helps in scoping the legal contract and setting business priorities for the implementation project. It provides an interactive discovery workflow to refine where S/4HANA fits in the business.
    • SAP Cloud ALM can import the DDA Excel report to automatically create a project, helping define phases, sprints, and milestones.

N+2 Scenario

In an N+2 scenario, where multiple projects are running in parallel, it is crucial to ensure that changes in one project do not negatively impact others. This requires:

  • Regular Synchronization: Regularly synchronize changes across projects to ensure alignment.
  • Dependency Management: Use dependency checks to prevent errors due to wrong transport sequences.
  • Testing: Conduct thorough testing in separate environments to ensure changes are compatible across projects.

By leveraging tools like SAP Cloud ALM and managing transport requests effectively, organizations can successfully run parallel S/4 migration projects while maintaining alignment and ensuring smooth retrofitting.

 

[1] Transport Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Hello,

Thank you very much for your question. I'm very sorry for the late response.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves the issue?

To automate the monthly closing of projects only for the current month, you need to ensure that the system processes only the items relevant to the current month and not future months. Here are some steps you can follow:

  1. Review Billing Dates: Ensure that the billing dates are correctly set for each transaction. For example, if a billing date is set for May 21, it should be processed in June, not May.

  2. Configure Settlement Jobs: When setting up the job for monthly closing, make sure to specify the correct parameters that limit the processing to the current month. This might involve setting the job to recognize only transactions with billing dates within the current month.

  3. Use Correct Input Parameters: In the job setup, use ‚Äòperiod-end date‚Äô as the input parameter instead of ‚Äòas on date‚Äô. 3325419 - Failed to provide correct date for Job Template ‚ÄòProduction Settlement in Parallel Ledgers‚Äô or ; ‚ÄòActual Settlement for Production Orders/Process Orders & Product Cost Collectors‚Äô This ensures that only transactions up to the end of the current period are processed.

  4. Check System Settings: Verify that the system settings are configured to handle monthly closings correctly. This includes checking any flags or options that might affect how transactions are processed.

  5. Test the Configuration: Before fully implementing the job, run tests to ensure that it processes only the current month‚Äôs transactions and does not inadvertently include future transactions.

By following these steps, you can ensure that your monthly closing request processing job handles only the current month‚Äôs transactions, avoiding issues with future transactions being processed prematurely.

[1] 3325419 - Failed to provide correct date for Job Template 'Production Settlement in Parallel Ledgers' or ; 'Actual Settlement for Production Orders/Process Orders & Product Cost Collectors'

Kind regards, Henrike

entry.title: PM order attachments downloads from SAP Business Document Service - BDS
entry.content:
We develop simple program that enables the download of attachments linked to PM (Plant Maintenance) orders from the SAP Business Document Service (BDS). It confirms the PM order data from AUFK, determines attachment relationships via BDS connection tables, and exports the attached files (e.g., PDFs, JPGs, DOCs) to a specified local directory in a readable format. This tool enables download of multiple attachments per order and ensures that users can access and store PM-related documentation outside of SAP for reporting, analysis.
Take a note that this program does not provide download of attachments if they are saved in Generic Object Services. You can check you BDS tables: BDS_CON00 | CLASSNAME: 'BUS2007' -> OBJECT_KEY (PM order), OBJECT_KEY -> LOIO_ID, stored documents in final BDS_CONT1 table for confirmation of BDS use.

Code base of our solution:

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report ypm_download_pm_attachments
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*&
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
REPORT ypm_download_pm_attachments.

TABLES: aufk.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* SELECTION SCREEN
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
SELECTION-SCREEN BEGIN OF BLOCK b1 WITH FRAME TITLE TEXT-001.
*  PARAMETERS: p_aufnr TYPE aufk-aufnr OBLIGATORY, "PM Order Number
  SELECT-OPTIONS s_aufnr FOR aufk-aufnr NO INTERVALS.

  PARAMETERS:  p_path  TYPE string     OBLIGATORY. "Local Folder Path
SELECTION-SCREEN END OF BLOCK b1.

*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
* EVENTS
*----------------------------------------------------------------------*
AT SELECTION-SCREEN ON VALUE-REQUEST FOR p_path.
  " Provide F4 help to browse for a local directory
  cl_gui_frontend_services=>directory_browse(
    EXPORTING
      window_title    = 'Select a Folder'
      initial_folder  = 'C:\'
    CHANGING
      selected_folder = p_path
    EXCEPTIONS
      cntl_error      = 1
      OTHERS          = 2
  ).
  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    MESSAGE 'Could not open directory browser.' TYPE 'E'.
  ENDIF.

START-OF-SELECTION.
  " Data declarations
  DATA: lv_object_key TYPE bds_typeid,
        lv_class_name TYPE bds_clsnam VALUE 'BUS2007', " Business Object for PM Order
        lv_class_type TYPE bds_clstyp VALUE 'BO',      " Class Type for Business Object
        lv_full_path  TYPE string,
        lv_counter    TYPE i VALUE 0.

  " This internal table will receive ALL document data and properties
  DATA: lt_documents TYPE TABLE OF bapicompon.
  DATA: lt_signatures TYPE TABLE OF bapisignat.
  DATA: lt_content TYPE TABLE OF bapiconten.
  DATA: ls_content LIKE LINE OF lt_content.
  "This internal table will be used to fetch individual document content
  DATA: lt_signatures_docs TYPE TABLE OF bapisignat.
  DATA: lt_components_docs TYPE TABLE OF bapicompon.
  DATA: ls_sig LIKE LINE OF lt_signatures.

  LOOP AT s_aufnr INTO DATA(lr_aufnr). ""PM order number loop

    "Validate PM Order existence
    SELECT SINGLE aufnr FROM aufk
      INTO @DATA(lv_aufnr)
      WHERE aufnr = @LR_aufnr-low.

    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
      WRITE: / |Order '{ lr_aufnr-low }' not found in table AUFK.|.
    ENDIF.

    lv_object_key = lv_aufnr.

    "Get ALL attachments and their data in a SINGLE call
    REFRESH: lt_signatures, lt_documents, lt_content.
    CALL FUNCTION 'BDS_BUSINESSDOCUMENT_GET_TAB'
      EXPORTING
        classname     = lv_class_name
        classtype     = lv_class_type
        object_key    = lv_object_key
      TABLES
        signature     = lt_signatures
        components    = lt_documents
        content       = lt_content
      EXCEPTIONS
        nothing_found = 1
        OTHERS        = 2.

    IF sy-subrc <> 0 OR lt_documents IS INITIAL.
      WRITE: / |No attachments found for PM Order '{ lv_aufnr }'.|.
    ENDIF.
    WRITE: /.
    WRITE: / |Downloading attachments for PM Order: { lv_aufnr }|.
    ULINE.

    DATA: ls_doc TYPE bapicompon.

    "Loop through the returned documents table
    LOOP AT lt_documents INTO ls_doc. ""Documents loop

      REFRESH: lt_content, lt_signatures_docs, lt_components_docs.
      CLEAR: ls_sig.

      IF ls_doc-doc_count IS INITIAL.
        " Skip if there is no content in the document
        CONTINUE.
      ENDIF.

      AT NEW doc_count.

        " Clear previous content tables
        READ TABLE lt_signatures INTO ls_sig WITH KEY doc_count = ls_doc-doc_count.
        IF  sy-subrc = 0.

          CALL FUNCTION 'BDS_DOCUMENT_GET_TABLE'
            EXPORTING
*             CLIENT          = SY-MANDT
              doc_id          = ls_sig-doc_id
*             BINARY_FLAG     = 'X'
            TABLES
              signature       = lt_signatures_docs
              components      = lt_components_docs
              content         = lt_content
*             ASCII_CONTENT   =
            EXCEPTIONS
              nothing_found   = 1
              parameter_error = 2
              not_allowed     = 3
              error_kpro      = 4
              internal_error  = 5
              not_authorized  = 6
              OTHERS          = 7.
          IF sy-subrc <> 0.
*error
          ENDIF.

        ENDIF.

      ENDAT.

      " The filename is available directly in the  COMP_ID field.
      DATA(lv_file_name) = ls_doc-comp_id.

      " Full local path and trigger the download
      TRY.
          lv_full_path = p_path && '\' && lv_aufnr && '_' && lv_file_name.

          cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_download(
            EXPORTING
              filename                = lv_full_path
              filetype                = 'BIN' " Use binary mode for all file types
            CHANGING
              data_tab                = lt_content
            EXCEPTIONS
              file_write_error        = 1
              no_batch                = 2
              gui_refuse_filetransfer = 3
              invalid_type            = 4
              OTHERS                  = 5
          ).

          IF sy-subrc = 0.
            ADD 1 TO lv_counter.
            WRITE: / |SUCCESS: Downloaded '{ lv_file_name }'|.
          ELSE.
            WRITE: / |ERROR: Failed to download '{ lv_file_name }'. SY-SUBRC: { sy-subrc }|.
          ENDIF.

        CATCH cx_root.
          MESSAGE 'A front-end services error occurred. Check your SAP GUI installation and authorizations.' TYPE 'E'.
      ENDTRY.

    ENDLOOP. ""Documents loop
  ENDLOOP. ""PM order number loop

  ULINE.
  WRITE: / |Target Directory: { p_path }|.
  WRITE: / |Download complete. Total files downloaded: { lv_counter }|.


The program outputs all attachments into the selected folder, with the PM order number concatenated at the beginning of each file name.

For archiving purposes different approach should be considered in order to be able to run program in background and have some kind of mass monitoring for successful downloads and logs. However, for quick download of few PM order's attachments this program could suffice.
I hope this saves some time to someone.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves the issue?

To allocate incidental costs such as customs clearance fees, unloading charges, and warehousing fees to imported raw materials in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, you can follow these steps:

1. CBC Scope Items

For this process, you should consider the following scope items:

  • Procurement of Services (22Z): Blog Series: SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition ‚Äì 0‚Ä¶ - SAP Community This scope item covers the procurement process, including service procurement which can be used for incidental costs.
  • Direct Procurement with Inbound Delivery (2TX): Blog Series: SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition ‚Äì 0‚Ä¶ - SAP Community This scope item includes the inbound delivery process, which is relevant for handling imported goods.
  • Manual Transportation Planning (6W2): Blog Series: SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition ‚Äì 0‚Ä¶ - SAP Community This scope item is useful for planning transportation, which can include incidental costs.
  • Freight Settlement (6W4): Blog Series: SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition ‚Äì 0‚Ä¶ - SAP Community This scope item deals with the settlement of freight costs, which can be part of the incidental costs.

2. Applications (Apps)

The process of allocating incidental costs can be executed in the following apps:

  • Create Purchase Order: Use this app to create purchase orders for the imported raw materials and include incidental costs as service items.
  • Create Supplier Invoice: This app is used to record the supplier invoices for the incidental costs.
  • Post Goods Movement: Use this app to record the receipt of goods and allocate costs to the inventory.

These steps will help ensure that incidental costs are properly allocated to the respective purchased raw materials, impacting inventory valuation and financial reporting.

Kind regards, Henrike

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves the issue?

To find the earliest inbound posting date and the latest outbound posting date for a product using CDS views, you can follow these steps:

Steps to Create CDS Views

  1. Identify Relevant CDS Views:

    • Use the View Browser app to search for CDS views that contain the fields you need. For inbound and outbound posting dates, you might consider using I_MaterialDocumentItem_2 which contains fields related to material documents and posting dates.

  2. Create a Custom CDS View:

    • Open the Custom CDS Views app.
    • Select I_MaterialDocumentItem_2 as your primary data source.
    • Add necessary fields such as Material, Plant, Posting Date, and any other relevant fields.
    • Use filters or calculations to determine the earliest and latest posting dates.

  3. Join with Other CDS Views:

    • If you need additional fields like Warehouse, you can join your custom CDS view with other views that contain these fields.

  4. Publish and Test:

    • Once your CDS view is configured, publish it and test using tools like Postman or directly within SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

Example Code

Here is a simple example of how you might define a view to get the earliest and latest posting dates:

DEFINE VIEW Z_ProductPostingDates AS SELECT FROM I_MaterialDocumentItem_2 [Comparison of Report Development in 3SL & 2SL in S...](https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blogs-by-sap/comparison-of-report-development-in-3sl-2sl-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public/ba-p/13578738)
{
  key Material,
  key Plant,
  MIN(PostingDate) AS EarliestInboundDate,
  MAX(PostingDate) AS LatestOutboundDate
}
WHERE GoodsMovementType IN ('101', '261')
GROUP BY Material, Plant

Additional Resources

  • You can refer to SAP‚Äôs documentation or community blogs for more detailed guidance and examples.

If you need further assistance or a video tutorial, you might want to check SAP‚Äôs official learning resources or community forums. Virtual Data Model and CDS Views - Material Stock at Posting Date

[1] Comparison of Report Development in 3SL & 2SL in S...
[2] Virtual Data Model and CDS Views - Material Stock at Posting Date
Kind regards, Henrike

entry.title: Lean Services Enablement in Commercial Project Management
entry.content:
Introduction

Commercial Project Management (CPM) provides functions that address the core business process requirements of companies that offer project-based services to their customers. These functions cover multiple processes in an end-to-end scenario spanning the selling, planning, execution, monitoring, and controlling of projects. A core aspect of this process involves the various resource types for carrying out financial activities like Activity, Expense, Human Resource, Material and Revenue.

The SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0 release introduces Lean Services in CPM which can be used as a resource type for carrying out the financial activities. This extends the earlier introduction of Lean Service Components within Project System (PS) delivered in SAP S/4 HANA 2023 FPS1, providing a seamless experience across both CPM and PS. This blog outlines the essential configuration steps and system prerequisites for activating and integrating Lean Services in CPM, thereby enabling efficient handling of external procurement.

Types of Lean Services

  • Planned Lean Services: Services for which the quantity and exact value is known at the time of creating the purchase requisition.
  • Unplanned Lean Services: Services for which the exact value is not known at the time of creating the purchase requisition. Instead of a fixed price, you enter a value limit that must not be exceeded.

CPM now supports the integration of both Planned and Unplanned Lean Services. This functionality is enabled through the steps described below:

Prerequisite Configuration

  • Define the Resource Types for Lean Service in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Define Resource Types.Figure 1: Resource Types for Lean Services Enablement
  • Assign the resource types to the plan scenario for which financial plan will be done in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Link Plan Scenario to Resource Types.Figure 2: Link Plan Scenario to Resource Types for Lean Services Enablement

Integration with Project System (PS)

The following frameworks in CPM now support Lean Services integration with PS:

Import Planned data to CPM: In order to import data from objects in Project System (PS) into a financial plan, add the import method in IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Import Data -> Make Settings for Import Methods.

Figure 3: Import Methods for Lean Services Enablement

Add the Import Methods to Import Strategies in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Import Data -> Make Settings for Import Strategies.

Figure 4: Import Strategies for Lean Services Enablement

Transfer Planned data to PS: In order to transfer planned data such as quantities, cost, or revenue to business objects in backend systems, add the transfer method in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Transfer Data -> Make Settings for Transfer Methods.

Figure 5: Transfer Methods for Lean Services Enablement

Add the Transfer Methods to Transfer Strategies in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Transfer Data -> Make Settings for Transfer Strategies.

Figure 6: Transfer Strategies for Lean Services Enablement

Add the import and transfer strategies to the plan scenario in SPRO path: IMG-> Commercial Project Management -> Project Cost and Revenue Planning -> Link Plan Scenario to Version Types.

Figure 7: Link Plan Scenario to Version Types for Lean Services Enablement

Once the above configuration steps are completed, you can seamlessly import the planned data for Lean Service Components from PS, carry out your planning and send the planned data back to PS - just like any other resource type. 

The following example illustrates an end-to-end scenario starting with planning of Lean Service Components in PS followed by importing the planned data into CPM. Planning activities are then carried out in CPM and the planned data is transferred back to PS.

Planning of Lean Service Components in PS

Figure 8: Planning of Planned Lean Service Components in PS

Figure 9: Planning of Unplanned Lean Service Components in PS

 Planned data of Lean Service Components imported from PS to CPM successfully

Figure 10: Import Planned Data of Lean Services from PS into CPM

Planning of Lean Services in CPM

Figure 11: Planning of Lean Services in CPM

Transfer of Planned data from CPM to PS

Figure 12: Transfer of Planned Data of Lean Services from CPM to PS

Planned data transferred from CPM to PS successfully

Figure 13: Transfer of Planned Data from CPM to PS for Planned Lean Service

 Figure 14: Transfer of Planned Data from CPM to PS for Unplanned Lean Service

Additional Information

For more details on Lean Services, you may refer below links:

  • Planning Lean Services
  • Lean Service Enablement for Project Networks

entry.title: Simplifying Event Configuration with the "Not Contains" Operator for Job & Automation Monitoring
entry.content:
In Q2 2025, SAP Cloud ALM introduced an impactful feature in its Job & Automation Monitoring app: the Not Contains operator for the Job/Automation Name parameter. This addition is set to streamline Event Configuration, saving administrators' valuable time and effort.

 

Why "Not Contains" Matters

Previously, administrators faced challenges when trying to exclude specific job names from events. The process involved manually entering each job name with the "is not" condition, a tedious task.

Scenario 1: One-Time Jobs

Imagine you're an administrator managing a complex customer system, where unique jobs are scheduled to run once daily. These jobs are named with a static prefix, such as "TEST," followed by a dynamic value like the current date and time. For instance, you might see job names like Test2025081201000, Test2025081301000, and so forth. As these jobs accumulate daily, managing them can become quite a task.

Previously, if you wanted to set up a generic runtime event to ignore all these unique jobs, you faced a challenge. The system didn't allow you to use a pattern-based exclusion, such as ignoring all job names containing "TEST." Instead, you had to manually enter each job name into the filter using the is not condition. This meant updating the filter every day, which was not only time-consuming but also increased the risk of errors.

Thankfully, this new feature enables a more efficient approach. By using the not contains operator for the Job/Automation Name parameter, you can easily set up a filter to ignore all jobs with names containing "TEST." This means you no longer have to manually update the filter daily, saving you time and reducing the potential for mistakes.

Scenario 2: Specific Name Patterns

Imagine a customer system where a runtime event was defined for a set of jobs with names containing the pattern "FCFS." The threshold for these jobs was set at one hour, meaning that if any job with "FCFS" in its name exceeded this runtime, an alert would be triggered. However, the customer also wanted to establish a generic runtime event with a shorter threshold of 30 minutes for all other jobs.

Previously, users faced a significant hurdle: the system did not allow them to exclude jobs with the "FCFS" pattern from the generic runtime event. The only workaround was to manually enter each job into the filter using the is not condition, which was both time-consuming and prone to errors.

With this new feature, users can now easily set up alerts for jobs that do not contain "FCFS" in their names without the need for manual entry. This enhancement not only saves time but also reduces the risk of overlooking jobs that should be excluded from the generic runtime event.

 Embrace the Change

 The Not Contains operator is designed to speed up and improve event configuration. Whether you're dealing with one-time jobs or specific name patterns, this feature reduces hassle and enhances productivity. We encourage you to explore this new tool and experience the ease it brings to your workflow.

 Feel free to share your experiences with this feature and let us know how it has impacted your event configuration tasks.

SAP Cloud ALM  #Job&AutomationMonitoring #Job&AutomationMonitoringeventconfiguration #NotContains

Expert Portal

entry.title: Re: RAP on Dynamic Condition Tables ‚Äì Draft Enablement Ch...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question. I'm very sorry for the late response.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves the issue?

When dealing with dynamic tables in a RAP application, especially when draft functionality is crucial, there are several considerations and approaches you can explore:

  1. Draft Functionality in RAP:

    • Draft functionality allows users to work on temporary versions of data ABAP Restful Application Programming Model (RAP) - SAP Community before committing changes. It is typically supported in managed scenarios Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud - SAP Community where the CDS view is directly linked to a database table.
    • In your case, since the CDS view is implemented by a class, draft functionality is not directly supported. This is a limitation because the RAP framework requires a direct link to the database table for draft operations.

  2. Alternative Approaches:

    • Re-evaluate the CDS View Implementation: Consider if the dynamic nature of your tables can be handled differently. If possible, restructure the CDS view to directly expose the database tables, allowing draft functionality.
    • Custom Draft Handling: Implement custom logic to simulate draft behavior. This involves manually managing temporary data storage and retrieval, mimicking the draft operations.
    • Use of Side Effects: If draft functionality cannot be enabled, consider using side effects to update parent entries based on child entries dynamically.

  3. Considerations for Dynamic Data:

    • Dynamic Data Handling: Ensure that your application logic can handle changes in the underlying table structure. This might involve using dynamic SQL or flexible data models.
    • Testing and Validation: Thoroughly test the application to ensure that dynamic data handling does not introduce errors or inconsistencies.

  4. Consult Documentation and Community:

    • Review SAP documentation on RAP and draft functionality for any updates or alternative methods.
    • Engage with the SAP community to gather insights and experiences from other developers who might have faced similar challenges.

By exploring these approaches, you can find a suitable solution to enable draft functionality or effectively manage dynamic data in your RAP application.

[1] ABAP Restful Application Programming Model (RAP) - SAP Community
[2] Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud - SAP Community
Kind regards, Henrike

entry.title: Bellwethers on SAP Business Network: Key Indicators for Business - Heavy equipment
entry.content:
The New York times reported July 17 that the Consumer Price Index rose 2.7 further corroborating my observation that while freight spending on the network is up, actual freight volumes may not be keeping pace‚Äîpotentially indicating higher costs or inefficiencies. 

This inspired me to spend more time on economic bellwethers using SAP Business Network data and the new demand trends dashboard.

Heavy equipment as a Bellwether

Heavy equipment is considered an economic bellwether because demand for it closely reflects the state of major capital-intensive industries like construction, mining, infrastructure, and manufacturing‚Äîsectors that typically lead or lag the broader economy.

Heavy equipment is a long-term capital investment. Companies only purchase or lease this machinery when they‚Äôre confident in future demand, cash flow, and project pipelines.

Construction and infrastructure spending usually kick in early during economic recovery phases‚Äîmeaning equipment sales often rise before GDP growth accelerates.

Since heavy equipment is essential for site prep, grading, and material handling, it‚Äôs a leading indicator for housing starts and commercial development.

Heavy construction machinery & equipment spend on the network

Heavy equipment spend spans 5 classes on the network including earthmoving machinery, heavy equipment components building construction machinery and equipment and accessories, air lifts and paving equipment.

There a clear downward trend starting in March with a 24% drop in spending in Q2 compared to Q1. 

If current trends hold, H2 2025 spend is projected to be ~13.6% lower than H1 2025, continuing the declining pattern seen in Q2.  This does not bode well for the economy.

What are analysts saying?

According to Construction Briefing, the global construction equipment market is expected to see a decline in sales in 2025 before rebounding in the following years. This year‚Äôs anticipated 11% decline in sales reflects the damage to business confidence being done by the Trump administration‚Äôs inflationary import tariffs and the unpredictability of its policy making.

Sources:

Bellwether in business: What it is and why it matters

entry.title: Re: Journal Entry API XML example with item with 0% VAT tax
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question. I'm very sorry for the late response.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves the issue?

To send a Journal Entry (JE) XML document with a 0% VAT tax value via the SAP S/4 Public Cloud API, you need to ensure that the XML structure includes the necessary tax information. Here is a sample XML structure that you can use:

<soapenv:Envelope xmlns:soapenv="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" xmlns:sfin="http://sap.com/xi/SAPSCORE/SFIN">
    <soapenv:Header/>
    <soapenv:Body>
        <sfin:JournalEntryBulkCreateRequest>
            <MessageHeader>
                <CreationDateTime>2024-03-11T10:29:20.230Z</CreationDateTime>
            </MessageHeader>
            <JournalEntryCreateRequest>
                <MessageHeader>
                    <CreationDateTime>2024-03-11T10:29:20.230Z</CreationDateTime>
                </MessageHeader>
                <JournalEntry>
                    <OriginalReferenceDocumentType>BKPFF</OriginalReferenceDocumentType>
                    <BusinessTransactionType>RFBU</BusinessTransactionType>
                    <AccountingDocumentType>KR</AccountingDocumentType>
                    <DocumentHeaderText>Test JE Posting</DocumentHeaderText>
                    <CreatedByUser>SAP</CreatedByUser>
                    <CompanyCode>1010</CompanyCode>
                    <DocumentDate>2024-03-11</DocumentDate>
                    <PostingDate>2024-03-11</PostingDate>
                    <Item>
                        <GLAccount>0063001000</GLAccount>
                        <AmountInTransactionCurrency currencyCode="EUR">1000</AmountInTransactionCurrency>
                        <DebitCreditCode>S</DebitCreditCode>
                        <Tax>
                            <TaxCode>S0</TaxCode> <!-- 0% VAT Tax Code -->
                        </Tax>
                        <AccountAssignment>
                            <CostCenter>0010101101</CostCenter>
                        </AccountAssignment>
                    </Item>
                    <ProductTaxItem>
                        <TaxCode>S0</TaxCode>
                        <TaxItemClassification>MWS</TaxItemClassification>
                        <AmountInTransactionCurrency currencyCode="EUR">0</AmountInTransactionCurrency>
                        <TaxBaseAmountInTransCrcy currencyCode="EUR">1000</TaxBaseAmountInTransCrcy>
                    </ProductTaxItem>
                </JournalEntry>
            </JournalEntryCreateRequest>
        </sfin:JournalEntryBulkCreateRequest>
    </soapenv:Body>
</soapenv:Envelope>

Key Points:

  • Tax Code: Use a tax code that represents 0% VAT, such as ‚ÄòS0‚Äô.
  • ProductTaxItem Node: Ensure that the tax amount is set to 0 and the tax base amount matches the transaction amount.
  • Mandatory Fields: Include all mandatory fields such as TaxCode, TaxItemClassification, AmountInTransactionCurrency, and TaxBaseAmountInTransCrcy.

If you encounter errors like ‚ÄòTax statement item missing for tax code XXX‚Äô, ensure that all required tax information is correctly filled in the ProductTaxItem node. This includes specifying the tax code and ensuring the tax amount is correctly calculated and represented.

For more detailed examples and guidelines, you can refer to the SAP Community Blog. Payload Examples for API Journal Entry ‚Äì Post - SAP Community

[1] Payload Examples for API Journal Entry ‚Äì Post - SAP Community

Kind regards, Henrike

entry.title: Re: Discover SAM4U: The Easy Way to Extract Data for Consolidated Adoption Insights and Optimization
entry.content:
Hello Siarhei,

Thanks a lot for the useful information, I am currently trying to implement SAM4U to our systems but getting a dump. And to be honest there is no fix for the dump so far I searched. 

I believe there is a problem with the standart code, I was wondering if you ever had such problem ... 

Dump is;

Category ABAP programming erro
Runtime Errors DBSQL_INVALID_CURSOR
Except. CX_SY_OPEN_SQL_DB
ABAP: Program /SAM4U/SAPLBEX_DATASE
Application Component BC-SRV-LIM

And it seems the issue is with the code itself;

 

Source Code Extract

Line Code

968 get_json iv_input 'segment' lv_name.
969 TRANSLATE lv_name TO UPPER CASE.
970 ENDIF.
971 lv_client = sy-mandt.
972 IF lv_name IS INITIAL.
973 add_json_log ev_output 'E' 201 'Dataset Name is not Provided' ##NO_TEXT.
974 ELSE.
975 SELECT SINGLE *
976 FROM /sam4u/bexdset
977 INTO ls_dataset
978 WHERE name = lv_name.
979 IF ls_dataset-status <> 'R'.

981 ELSEIF ls_dataset-taskid IS INITIAL.

983 ELSEIF ls_dataset-lines IS NOT INITIAL.

985 ELSE.
986 DELETE FROM /sam4u/bexdpack
987 WHERE name = lv_name.
988 CALL FUNCTION 'SLIC_GET_LICENCE_NUMBER'
989 IMPORTING
990 license_number = lv_table.
991 CONCATENATE lv_table lv_table INTO lv_table.
992 lv_table = lv_table+0(16).
993 string_to_raw lv_table lv_xkey.
994 CLEAR ls_package.
995 ls_package-name = lv_name.
996
997 CASE lv_name.
>>>>> case_run_dataset_user user.
999 case_run_dataset user_reference.
1000 case_run_dataset user_profile.
1001 case_run_dataset user_classificat.
1002 case_run_dataset user_extend_data.
1003 case_run_dataset profile_comp.
1004 case_run_dataset profile.
1005 case_run_dataset role.
1006 case_run_dataset auth_obj_value.

entry.title: Simplifying Field Service with AI in SAP FSM
entry.content:
Introduction:

SAP field service management operations set up for any new company settings requires careful planning, which has become much easier with the help of built in cloud AI features. With the help of these smart tools companies in FSM helps with much better decision making. Which also helps the technicians to complete their work more efficiently since they will be getting real-time support, faster & for instance access to the information which they require and smart scheduling. This results in lesser delays, and much improved service quality.

 Prerequisites for SAP Cloud FSM:

  • Must have a valid license for SAP AI Units.
  • Premium AI features must be activated in FSM tenant.
  • Sufficient Historical Data (1000 activities with the execution Stage should be equal to CLOSE status in order to train the system)


Key AI Features in SAP FSM:

Below is the breakdown of the core AI functionalities available

1. Intelligent Filtering

  1. Assignment Duration Prediction
  2. Activity Summary
  3. Equipment Summary

 

-> Intelligent Filtering:

Intelligent Filtering will help by showing the most relevant technicians only for the job and automatically sorting. which is like having a smart assistant that understands the input. Instead of checking each customer manually system will sort them based on the requirements of the job, then you will be getting a list of customers who passed the requirements which leads to lesser time consumption and better accuracy.
For example, imagine you're a dispatcher in FSM who is trying to assign a technician to a service job, you have list of technicians, but not all of them are suitable for all tasks, some might be far away, some might not be having the right skills, and others might already busy with other service jobs assigned previously. so based on the below points we can perform the intelligent filtering.

  • What the job needs (Like skills, tools, etc.)
  • Which technicians are available to perform the service task
  • Who is nearby to perform the service task
  • Who has done the similar job well previously.

Why It‚Äôs Useful:

  • Lesser time consumption: No need to manually check the list of all customers.
  • Reduced errors: Selects only technicians who are qualified and are available.
  • Improved customer service: Faster and better matches which results in the quicker resolutions for the tasks.


Steps to Enable:

  1. Raise an Incident:
    • Go to your SAP support portal.
    • Create a request under the component: CEC-SRV-FSM-AI.
    • Mention that you have a valid license and want to activate Intelligent Filtering.
  2. SAP Will Enable the Feature:
    • Once the request is processed, SAP will activate the feature in your FSM environment.
  3. Verify in the FSM Portal:
    • Navigate to the Planning & Dispatching module.
    • You‚Äôll see technician suggestions ranked intelligently when assigning service calls.

Compared to the older Best Matching Technician plugin, Intelligent Filtering is smarter and much easier to use. The old plugin works based on business rules which has been set up for every company, like checking technician skills or distance. whereas Intelligent Filtering in FSM uses the AI to understand what exactly dispatcher is looking for in the technicians and it automatically suggests the best technicians available for the service task.  It is much faster, that means it supports natural language searches. And it also gives the extra insights like past equipment history (which is not available in the old plugin doesn‚Äôt offer).


-> Assignment Duration Prediction:

Assignment Duration Prediction can be seen during the dispatching of an activity which will provide the overview like how long it will take to complete the current service task, which technician will be suitable for this activity rather than dispatcher guessing how long it might take to complete the current service tasks.

It uses the data like below:

  • The type of service task which needs to be assigned
  • The technician‚Äôs past performance on the service tasks
  • Historical data which are similar to the current service task
  • Job priority and some other requirements

This will help the dispatchers to plan accurately and helps to avoid the delay.

 Why It‚Äôs Useful:

  •  Better scheduling: can avoid the overloading the technicians.
  • Lesser delays during the assignment of service tasks.

Steps to Enable:

  1. Training the (AI Model) system

You can do this in two easy ways:

  • Option A: Use the Settings Screen
    • Go to Settings and Configuration in FSM.
    • Click on Assignment Duration Prediction.
    • Select your training data and click Train.

 

  • Option B: Use a Sample Business Rule
    • Download the sample rule from SAP Help.
    • Upload it to your FSM system.
    • Add your technical contact and adjust the date range if needed.
    • Run the rule to train the model.
  1. Activate the Feature
  • Go to: Settings and Configuration ‚Üí Planning and Dispatching ‚Üí General Settings ‚Üí Activity Planning ‚Üí Additional Settings
  • Turn on the checkbox:
    ‚ÄúAllow assignment duration prediction for semi and fully automated scheduling‚Äù
  1. Start Using It
  • Use features like Auto-Scheduling or Best Matching Technician.
  • The system will now use predicted durations instead of planned ones when assigning jobs.

 

-> Activity Summary:

Activity summary is like an assistant who give you the overview of the activity like what technician was doing, it gives you the summarized explanation of activity in detail, it helps the dispatcher to understand the below points:

  • what types of jobs were completed by technicians?
  • how much time did they take to complete the activity?
  • Did any issue occur during the completion of activity?


Why It‚Äôs Useful:

  • with the help of activity summary dispatcher can save time as he doesn't have to go through each and every activity
  • Dispatcher can quickly understand how team is performing the activity using this feature
  • Can quickly identify if there is any issue which is occurring multiple times
  • Better decisions could be made with the help of summaries


 Steps to Enable

  1. Raise a Support Request
    • Go to the SAP Support Portal
    • Create a request under the component: CEC-SRV-FSM-AI
    • Mention that you want to enable Activity Summary along with other features.
  2. SAP Will Enable the Feature
    • Once approved, SAP will activate it in your FSM system
  3. Check in the FSM Portal
    • Go to the Planning and Dispatching module
    • You‚Äôll see AI-generated summaries for completed jobs

 

-> Equipment Summary:

Equipment Summary is similar to activity summary where in the activity summary we will be getting the summary of the completed activity but in the equipment summary we will be getting the summary of the equipment which will be used in the service tasks. it provides the details of the equipment which will be used in the service tasks which will help the dispatcher to make better decisions like.

  • Dispatcher can see which equipment was used for which service activity
  • how often did technician used this equipment
  • if there is any issue related to this equipment that can be seen in the equipment summary along with that, we can also see the performance of the equipment over time

Why It‚Äôs Useful:

  • it saves time by giving the summary of the equipment in an instance rather than going through the equipment history record
  • if there is any reoccurring issue that can be fixed with the help of this feature so it will be very useful for preventive maintenance activities


Steps to Enable:

  1. Go to Planning and Dispatching - Open the Planning and Dispatching module in FSM.
  2. Open a Service Call you can either click on a service call from the Dispatching Board or select one from the Service Calls list.
  3. Generate Equipment Summary
    • Inside the service call, go to the General Information tab.
    • Scroll down to the Insights section.
    • Click the button to generate the equipment summary.
  4. Review and Use the Summary
    • The system will show a short, AI-generated summary of the equipment‚Äôs history.

 

 

Conclusion:

SAP FSM‚Äôs AI features help the service teams to work much faster and smarter by reducing the manual effort and better decision making.

entry.title: Customer Invoice to Sales Order Reversal Process with Minimal Customizations
entry.content:
Backend System ‚Äì SAP S/4HANA 2020FP02

 

Business Scenario

There was a scenario where the business generated a large number of incorrect invoices due to faulty automation in the process from sales orders to invoicing. As a result, it became necessary to perform bulk operations to cancel the invoices, reverse the PGIs, delete the deliveries, and reject the associated sales orders. To address this unique situation, a solution was provided with minimal customization.

 

  • Bulk Invoice Cancelation

A LSMW was provided to handle the cancellation of the identified invoices. The relevant user was able to upload the necessary invoice data and perform bulk cancellations efficiently.

 

  • PGI Reversal

As a solution for the PGI reversal, a custom upload program was developed using the standard BAPI WS_REVERSE_GOODS_ISSUE. Users could upload an Excel file in the required format and execute the program to reverse the PGIs in bulk. The program also included a test run option to help identify any potential issues with the deliveries before performing the actual reversal.

The main reason for developing this custom solution was a specific business requirement: the ability to reverse PGIs based on the posting date, which is not feasible in standard transaction VL09 for bulk processing.

While VL09 allows individual PGI reversals and provides the option to change the reversal date, it does not support bulk processing. Hence, a custom solution was necessary to meet the business requirement for reversing multiple PGIs at once with the ability to specify a reversal date.

 

  • Delevery Deletion and Sales Order Rejection

Delivery deletion and sales order rejection can be performed simultaneously using transaction code VKM4. Deliveries that have already been reversed can be deleted through this transaction. On the selection screen, the delivery numbers should be entered in the 'SD Document' field, and the 'Deliveries' checkbox must be selected to ensure proper filtering and execution.

 

The user can then execute transaction VKM4. On the next screen, the 'Processing Status' checkbox should be selected, and the user should choose the 'Reject' option to proceed with the delivery deletion and sales order rejection.

 

The user has the option to decide whether to perform both delivery deletion and sales order rejection simultaneously, or to carry out only the delivery deletion. Based on the requirement, if both actions are needed, the user must select a rejection reason from the search help, click the 'Copy' button, and then click 'Save' to complete the process. In this case, the entire sales order will be rejected using the rejection reason specified in VKM4.

 

 

On the other hand, if the user's requirement is to delete only the delivery without rejecting the sales order, the 'Reason for Rejection' field should be left empty and no value should be selected from the search help. As with the previous case, the user should then click the 'Copy' button followed by the 'Save' button to complete the delivery deletion process.

 

Special thanks to the @Chathuranga_Rajapaksha

entry.title: SAP EWM - Deconsolidation of Handling Unit Internally in Warehouse
entry.content:
The deconsolidation process involves dividing the larger shipment into smaller units, checking their accuracy and condition, and preparing them for final delivery. Efficient load deconsolidation is vital to ensure accurate inventory management, reduce errors and improve overall efficiency. Deconsolidation activity is observed in various industries such as Food & Beverages, Textile, Fashion, Retail, Automotive and Aftermarket sales etc. Deconsolidation in EWM is mainly observed during Inbound but can be performed as an Internal activity as well. 

I have attempted to showcase how it can be achieved in the SAP EWM. 

Configuration:

1) Define Storage types 

SCM EWM > EWM > Master Data > Define Storage Types

Storage type where stock is putawayed when received in a warehouse.

Deconsolidation Work center storage type.

Storage where deconsolidated stock will be kept, from where stock will be picked directly for outbound orders.

Create Activity area, Create Bins and do Bin sorting. 

2) Define POSC

SCM EWM > EWM > Cross-Process Settings> Warehouse Task> Define Process-Oriented Storage Control

3) Define Work Center 

SCM EWM > EWM > Master Data > Work Center > Define Work Center

Assign storage process for deconsolidation.

4) Define Strategies for Stock Removal and Putaway

a) Removal Strategy

SCM EWM> EWM> Goods Issue Process > Strategies > Specify Storage Type Search Sequence

b) Putaway Strategy 

SCM EWM > EWM > Goods Receipt Process > Strategies > Storage Type Search> Define Storage Type Search Sequence for Putaway

Assign Storage Types to Storage Type Search Sequence

Specify Storage Type Search Sequence for Putaway

5) Define Warehouse Process type

SCM EWM > EWM > Cross-Process Settings > Warehouse Task > Define Warehouse Process Type

Assign Storage process in warehouse process type.

Master Data:

Use T code /SCWM/TWORKST to maintain Workcenter Bin

Testing:

1) Use T code /SCWM/ADHU to create a warehouse task for a mix Handling Unit.Enter HU number and click on execute. Click on Create/ Create+Save, HU will be picked, and warehouse task will be created move HU to Deconsolidation Workcenter. 

Confirm open Warehouse task and HU will be moved to Deconsolidation work center.

2) Use /SCWM/DCONS to open Deconsolidation work center.

Create new Handling units and pack quantity into new Handling unit.

Once deconsolidation completed, Click on Complete Process step for HU. 

Note: Recommended to complete HU step one by one to avoid locking. 

HU labels can be printed and pasted. Click on Refresh a new WT will be created to move HU to Final storage. 

All the above steps can be performed in RFUI as well.

entry.title: Re: Regarding cross Tier , Cross 'ABAP Language" Cloud de...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question. I'm very sorry for the late response.

Can you please check whether the following information (GenAI was used to help generate this content) solves the issue?

Implementing a classic unreleased BADI by writing the core logic in a Tier-1 class and using a Tier-2 wrapper class to wrap any unreleased objects is a strategic approach to minimize technical debt. This method allows you to prepare for future upgrades by ensuring that your logic is already in a cloud-ready format once the BADI is released. However, there are some considerations:

  1. Cross-Tier Compatibility: Ensure that the Tier-1 class and Tier-2 wrapper are compatible with the Tier-3 BADI. This involves checking that the interfaces and data types used are consistent across tiers.

  2. Upgrade Stability: While this approach is designed to enhance upgrade stability, it is crucial to test thoroughly to ensure that the integration between tiers does not introduce unexpected issues during upgrades.

  3. Documentation and Guidelines: SAP provides guidelines on using tiers for extensibility, but specific documentation for your approach might not be available. It is recommended to follow SAP‚Äôs general guidelines for extensibility ABAP Cloud ‚Äì SAP S/4HANA extensibility ‚Äì May 2023 ‚Ä¶ - SAP Community and API usage.

Unfortunately, there is no specific SAP Note, KBA, or blog that directly supports this approach. However, the concept of using tiers for extensibility SAP S/4HANA Extensibility Options For Clean Core J‚Ä¶ - SAP Community is discussed in various SAP resources, emphasizing the importance of using released APIs and extension points for upgrade stability.

[1] ABAP Cloud ‚Äì SAP S/4HANA extensibility ‚Äì May 2023 ... - SAP Community
[2] SAP S/4HANA Extensibility Options For Clean Core J... - SAP Community
Kind regards, 
Henrike

entry.title: Re: How to delete an entry in the Landscape Management, w...
entry.content:
Hello,

for the Service Type "SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry Environment" I would expect that these services have the Source: Imported.
You can verify this in the Details Section in LMS.

If my assumption is correct, then it is not possible to delete these systems manually. Only systems/services with the Source "Manual" or "Registered" can be manually deleted.

For other imported services (from SLIS) the process is as follows: They will be marked as deleted once the customer unsubscribes. They will be deleted with the next SLIS import once all use cases have the status "Not Configured" and all endpoints are deleted. Please refer to
Troubleshooting for Landscape Management 

If endpoints and Use Cases are clean, it can be expected that they should be gone soon. 

Best regards
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Customer Invoice to Sales Order Reversal Process with Minimal Customizations
entry.content:
To be honest, I am not clear with your post as to why the entire process to be reversed. Please answer the following:

  1. Was the customer information incorrect (e.g., wrong ship-to or bill-to party)?
  2. Did the invoice reflect the wrong material or product?
  3. Was the pricing condition misapplied (e.g., discounts, surcharges)?
  4. Were the taxes or duties calculated incorrectly?
  5. Was the currency incorrect or mismatched with the sales order?
  6. Were invoices created for sales orders that were not yet approved or released?
  7. Did the automation trigger invoices for orders that were meant to be blocked or rejected?
  8. Were duplicate invoices generated for the same sales order?
  9. Did the system create invoices for cancelled or already invoiced orders?
  10. Was there a mismatch between delivery quantity and invoiced quantity?
  11. Were invoices raised for partial deliveries that weren‚Äôt supposed to be billed yet?


Based on your answers to above query, a right direction can be shown
